G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a Custody Order may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the children.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7\u00a7 3, 10.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 209C, §§ 3, 10, and G.L. c. 208, § 28, as the children reside in Massachusetts, and this Court issued the prior Custody Order.

Knott v. Knott, 441 Mass. 754, 758 (2004.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a Custody Order may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the children.
Knott v. Knott, 441 Mass. 754, 758 (2004.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Knott v. Knott and does not concern G.L. c. 208, § 28, child custody, or modification standards. It addresses whether Massachusetts state courts have jurisdiction over private actions under the federal Telephone Consumer Protection Act. Because it neither discusses custody orders nor the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard, it does not support the claimed proposition.
Knott v. Knott, 441 Mass. 754, 758 (2004.relevant_excerpt: “We consider in this case whether an individual may commence a private action in a Massachusetts State court against telemarketers who violate a Federal statute, the Telephone Consumer Protection Act of 1991 (TCPA), 47 U.S.C. § 227 (2000), as amended.”

Bezio v. Patenaude, 381 Mass. 563, 576 (.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in modification proceedings.
Bezio v. Patenaude, 381 Mass. 563, 576 (.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses standards in guardianship/custody disputes and explains the relationship between the ‘parental fitness’ and ‘best interests of the child’ tests, but it does not address modification proceedings (e.g., modification of prior custody or support orders between parents) as such. The court emphasizes that both tests must be considered together and that natural parents should be denied custody only if unfit, which is materially different from stating that in modification proceedings the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration. Thus, the case does not directly support the proposition as framed.
Bezio v. Patenaude, 381 Mass. 563, 576 (.relevant_excerpt: “To the extent that cases such as the one at bar may be decided with reference to a particular test or standard, we believe that the critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child. Neither the ‘parental fitness’ test nor the ‘best interests of the child’ test is properly applied to the exclusion of the other.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in modification proceedings.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reiterates that in custody determinations, the core inquiry is what is in the "best interests of the child," and it discusses how the judge must weigh all relevant factors under that standard. While the case focuses on an initial custody determination rather than a post-judgment modification proceeding, it cites and applies the settled Massachusetts principle that the child’s best interests are paramount in custody matters, which is the same standard governing modification; thus it supports the general proposition about the primacy of best interests in this context.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012.relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … [whose] findings … ‘must stand unless they are plainly wrong.’ However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’”

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239, 248 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: A parent’s inability to provide stable care due to changes in employment and/or personal circumstances constitutes a material change in circumstances justifying modification of custody or visitation arrangements.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an initial divorce judgment and associated abuse‑prevention order, not a modification of an existing custody or visitation order based on later‑arising changes in a parent’s employment or personal circumstances. The custody and visitation rulings are grounded in findings of severe domestic abuse, parental alienation, and risk of emotional harm to the child—not on instability of the father’s employment or personal life as a material change. The case does not analyze or apply any ‘material change in circumstances’ standard to justify modification on those grounds, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In making a decision about legal or physical custody, a judge ‘shall consider whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31… Furthermore, in such cases the judge ‘shall consider evidence of past or present abuse toward a parent or child as a factor contrary to the best interest of the child.’… Here, the rebuttable presumption applied…. The judge’s decision to suspend visitation for one year is also supported by his extensive findings that… the father had engaged in physical, emotional, and financial abuse of the mother… and… damaged the mother’s relationship with the child.”}

E.N.O. v. L.M.M., 429 Mass. 824, 829\u20.proposition: A parent’s inability to provide stable care due to changes in employment and/or personal circumstances constitutes a material change in circumstances justifying modification of custody or visitation arrangements.
E.N.O. v. L.M.M., 429 Mass. 824, 829\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a Probate Court may order visitation for a de facto parent and applies a best-interests-of-the-child analysis. It does not discuss modification of existing custody or visitation orders based on a parent’s instability, employment changes, or personal circumstances, nor does it articulate any rule about what constitutes a ‘material change in circumstances.’ Accordingly, it does not support the proposition claimed.
E.N.O. v. L.M.M., 429 Mass. 824, 829\u20.relevant_excerpt: “The Probate Court’s equity jurisdiction is broad, extending to the right to authorize visitation with a child… A judge, therefore, should evaluate a child’s best interests in light of the specific circumstances.… Thus, on these facts, the best interests of the child require that the plaintiff, as the child’s de facto parent, be allowed temporary visitation with the child.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Massachusetts Appeals Court has emphasized the importance of ensuring that a child’s custodial environment provides stability and consistency.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The decision is from the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court, not the Massachusetts Appeals Court, so it cannot accurately be cited as the Appeals Court emphasizing anything. Additionally, while the case discusses the best interests of the child and factors in relocation, it does not specifically frame its analysis in terms of ensuring ‘stability and consistency’ of the custodial environment as a distinct emphasized principle. The proposition therefore misidentifies the court and overstates the particular articulation of stability/consistency drawn from this opinion.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 403 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: The Massachusetts Appeals Court has emphasized the importance of ensuring that a child’s custodial environment provides stability and consistency.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames custody decisions around the children’s welfare and emphasizes minimizing disruption and fostering a healthy environment. In affirming sole custody to the mother and rejecting joint custody, the court stresses the need for a custodial arrangement that avoids continued parental conflict and reflects the children’s primary attachment, which inherently promotes stability and consistency in the custodial environment.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 596 (1.proposition: Modification is also warranted where a parent routinely violates the terms of a prior custody arrangement, resulting in instability for the children.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 596 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its effect on a child in initial or ongoing custody determinations. It does not address modification standards or discuss a parent’s routine violation of an existing custody order as a basis for modifying custody. Nothing in the reasoning or holding supports the specific proposition that modification is warranted where a parent routinely violates prior custody terms causing instability.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 596 (1.relevant_excerpt: "Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. ... Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking."

Houle v. Houle, 38 Mass. App. Ct. 638, 6.raw_text: Houle v. Houle, 38 Mass. App. Ct. 638, 641 (1995)
Houle v. Houle, 38 Mass. App. Ct. 638, 6.proposition: Modification is also warranted where a parent routinely violates the terms of a prior custody arrangement, resulting in instability for the children.
Houle v. Houle, 38 Mass. App. Ct. 638, 6.support_reasoning: This opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case addressing sentencing, evidentiary issues, juror competency, and a Rodriquez charge in an aggravated rape and kidnapping prosecution. It does not involve family law, custody, or modification of custody orders, nor does it discuss parental violations of custody arrangements or instability for children. Therefore it cannot support the cited proposition about custody modification standards.
Houle v. Houle, 38 Mass. App. Ct. 638, 6.relevant_excerpt: The judgments on the convictions of kidnapping are vacated, and those indictments are remanded to the Superior Court for the imposition of sentences to run concurrently with the sentences imposed on the convictions of aggravated rape. The remaining judgments are affirmed.

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 259 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Defendant’s work schedule, frequent failure to exercise parenting time, and reliance on third parties who are not vetted or familiar to the Plaintiff, constitute a significant and ongoing material change in circumstances.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The case does discuss work schedules and use of childcare, but it holds that the mother’s hectic work schedule and reliance on third-party childcare did NOT constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting modification of custody. The court emphasizes that a parent who works outside the home, even with a hectic schedule, may still be the appropriate primary caretaker and that these facts, as found, were not a basis for changing custody. Thus, the opinion contradicts, rather than supports, the proposition that such factors themselves amount to a significant and ongoing material change in circumstances.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “We note, first, that a parent who works outside the home, even one with a ‘hectic’ schedule, may still be the appropriate primary caretaker and that, standing alone, such employment would not warrant a custody modification. Second, by the time of trial, the probate judge found that positive changes in the mother’s work schedule ‘allowed her to spend more time with the minor child.’ … Thus, to the extent that changes in the mother’s work schedule did occur, they were not changes warranting a modification in the custody arrangement.”
